**Thurl Arthur Ravenscroft** ([/ˈθɜːrl ˈreɪvənzkrɒft/](/wiki/Help:IPA/English
"Help:IPA/English"); February 6, 1914 – May 22, 2005) was an American [voice
actor](/wiki/Voice_actor "Voice actor") and [bass](/wiki/Bass_\(voice_type\)
"Bass \(voice type\)") singer known as the booming voice behind [Tony the
Tiger](/wiki/Tony_the_Tiger "Tony the Tiger") in [Kellogg's](/wiki/Kellogg%27s
"Kellogg's") [Frosted Flakes](/wiki/Frosted_Flakes "Frosted Flakes") for more
than five decades. He was also the uncredited vocalist for the song "[You're a
Mean One, Mr. Grinch](/wiki/You%27re_a_Mean_One,_Mr._Grinch "You're a Mean
One, Mr. Grinch")" from the classic [Christmas television
special](/wiki/Christmas_television_special "Christmas television special"),
[Dr. Seuss](/wiki/Dr._Seuss "Dr. Seuss")' _[How the Grinch Stole
Christmas!](/wiki/How_the_Grinch_Stole_Christmas!_\(TV_special\) "How the
Grinch Stole Christmas! \(TV special\)")_[1]

Ravenscroft did some voice-over work and singing for
[Disney](/wiki/The_Walt_Disney_Company "The Walt Disney Company") in both the
films and the attractions at [Disneyland](/wiki/Disneyland "Disneyland")
(which were later featured at [Walt Disney World](/wiki/Walt_Disney_World
"Walt Disney World")). The best known of these attractions are [Haunted
Mansion](/wiki/Haunted_Mansion "Haunted Mansion") as a singing bust, [Country
Bear Jamboree](/wiki/Country_Bear_Jamboree "Country Bear Jamboree"), [Mark
Twain Riverboat](/wiki/Mark_Twain_Riverboat "Mark Twain Riverboat"), [Pirates
of the Caribbean](/wiki/Pirates_of_the_Caribbean_\(attraction\) "Pirates of
the Caribbean \(attraction\)"), [Disneyland
Railroad](/wiki/Disneyland_Railroad "Disneyland Railroad"), and [Walt Disney's
Enchanted Tiki Room](/wiki/Walt_Disney%27s_Enchanted_Tiki_Room "Walt Disney's
Enchanted Tiki Room") as "Fritz". His voice acting career began in 1940 and
lasted until his death in 2005 at age 91.[2]

## Early life and
career[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Thurl_Ravenscroft&action=edit&section=1 "Edit
section: Early life and career")]

Ravenscroft left his native [Norfolk, Nebraska](/wiki/Norfolk,_Nebraska
"Norfolk, Nebraska"), in 1933 for [California](/wiki/California "California"),
where he studied at Otis Art Institute. He achieved early success as part of a
singing group called [The Mellomen](/wiki/The_Mellomen "The Mellomen"). The
Mellomen can be heard on many popular recordings of the [Big
Band](/wiki/Big_Band "Big Band") Era, including backup for [Bing
Crosby](/wiki/Bing_Crosby "Bing Crosby"), [Frankie Laine](/wiki/Frankie_Laine
"Frankie Laine"), [Spike Jones](/wiki/Spike_Jones "Spike Jones"), [Jo
Stafford](/wiki/Jo_Stafford "Jo Stafford"), and [Rosemary
Clooney](/wiki/Rosemary_Clooney "Rosemary Clooney"). Their earliest
contribution to a Disney film was for
_[Pinocchio](/wiki/Pinocchio_\(1940_film\) "Pinocchio \(1940 film\)")_ (1940),
to which they contributed the song "Honest John." This was deleted from the
film but can still be heard in the supplements on the 2009 DVD. Despite the
song being cut off, Ravenscroft lent his voice to Monstro the whale in the
film. They also contributed to other Disney films, such as _[Alice in
Wonderland](/wiki/Alice_in_Wonderland_\(1951_film\) "Alice in Wonderland
\(1951 film\)")_ and _[Lady and the Tramp](/wiki/Lady_and_the_Tramp "Lady and
the Tramp")_. The group appeared on camera in a few episodes of the [Disney
anthology television series](/wiki/Disney_anthology_television_series "Disney
anthology television series"); in one instance recording a canine chorus for
_Lady and the Tramp_ and in another as a [barbershop
quartet](/wiki/Barbershop_quartet "Barbershop quartet") that reminds [Walt
Disney](/wiki/Walt_Disney "Walt Disney") of the name of the young newspaper
reporter _Gallegher_. Ravenscroft is also heard with the quartet on some of
the _[Merrie Melodies](/wiki/Merrie_Melodies "Merrie Melodies")_ and _[Looney
Tunes](/wiki/Looney_Tunes "Looney Tunes")_ with [Mel Blanc](/wiki/Mel_Blanc
"Mel Blanc") at [Warner Bros.](/wiki/Warner_Bros. "Warner Bros.") as well as
on radio "driving [Jack Benny](/wiki/Jack_Benny "Jack Benny") crazy" on [The
Jack Benny Program](/wiki/The_Jack_Benny_Program "The Jack Benny Program").
During [World War II](/wiki/World_War_II "World War II"), Ravenscroft served
as a civilian [navigator](/wiki/Flight_officer "Flight officer") contracted to
the [U.S. Air Transport
Command](/wiki/Air_Transport_Command_\(United_States_Air_Force\)#Record_of_the_ATC
"Air Transport Command \(United States Air Force\)"), spending five years
flying [courier](/wiki/Courier "Courier") missions across the north and south
[Atlantic](/wiki/Atlantic_Ocean "Atlantic Ocean"). Among the notables carried
on board his flights were [Winston Churchill](/wiki/Winston_Churchill "Winston
Churchill") and [Bob Hope](/wiki/Bob_Hope "Bob Hope"). As he told an
interviewer: "I flew Winston Churchill to a conference in Algiers and flew Bob
Hope to the troops a couple of times. So it was fun."[3]

Ravenscroft sang bass on Rosemary Clooney's "[This Ole
House](/wiki/This_Ole_House "This Ole House")", which went to No. 1 in both
the United States and Britain in 1954, as well as Stuart Hamblen's original
version of that same song. He sang on the soundtrack for [Ken
Clark](/wiki/Ken_Clark_\(actor\) "Ken Clark \(actor\)") as "Stewpot" in
_[South Pacific](/wiki/South_Pacific_\(1958_film\) "South Pacific \(1958
film\)")_ , one of the top-selling albums of the 1950s. Singing with the
[Johnny Mann](/wiki/Johnny_Mann "Johnny Mann") Singers,[4] his distinctive
bass can also be heard as part of the chorus on 28 of their albums that were
released during the 1960s and 1970s. He was also the bass singer on [Bobby
Vee](/wiki/Bobby_Vee "Bobby Vee")'s 1960 Liberty hit record "[Devil or
Angel](/wiki/Devil_or_Angel "Devil or Angel")". [Andy
Williams](/wiki/Andy_Williams "Andy Williams")' recording of "The 12 Days of
Christmas" features him as well. In the 1980s and 1990s, Ravenscroft was
narrator for the annual [Pageant of the Masters](/wiki/Pageant_of_the_Masters
"Pageant of the Masters") art show at the [Laguna Beach,
California](/wiki/Laguna_Beach,_California "Laguna Beach, California"),
Festival of the Arts.

He sang the opening songs for the two Disney serials used on _The Mickey Mouse
Club_ , _Boys of the Western Sea_ and _The Hardy Boys: Mystery of the
Applegate Treasure_.

He sang the "Twitterpatter Song" and "Thumper's Song" on the Disneyland record
_Peter Cottontail and other Funny Bunnies_.

On the Disneyland record _All About Dragons_ , he both provided the narration
and sang the songs "The Reluctant Dragon" and "The Loch Ness Monster".[5]

His voice was heard during the [Pirates of the
Caribbean](/wiki/Pirates_of_the_Caribbean_\(attraction\) "Pirates of the
Caribbean \(attraction\)") ride as well as the [Haunted
Mansion](/wiki/Haunted_Mansion "Haunted Mansion") at
[Disneyland](/wiki/Disneyland "Disneyland") as Uncle Theodore, the lead
vocalist of the [singing
busts](/wiki/List_of_Haunted_Mansion_characters#Singing_Busts "List of Haunted
Mansion characters") in the cemetery near the end of the ride.[6] He also
played the Narrator in _[The Story and Song From the Haunted
Mansion](/wiki/A_Spooky_Night_in_Disney%27s_Haunted_Mansion "A Spooky Night in
Disney's Haunted Mansion")_. Ravenscroft is also heard in the [Enchanted Tiki
Room](/wiki/Enchanted_Tiki_Room "Enchanted Tiki Room") as the voice of Fritz
the [Animatronics](/wiki/Animatronics "Animatronics") parrot. He was also the
voice of the Disneyland Railroad in the 1990s. Further roles include that of
The First Mate on The Mark Twain Riverboat and of the American bison head
named Buff at The Country Bear Jamboree.[7]

## Later
career[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Thurl_Ravenscroft&action=edit&section=2 "Edit
section: Later career")]

One of Ravenscroft's best-known uncredited works is as the vocalist for the
song "[You're a Mean One, Mr. Grinch](/wiki/You%27re_a_Mean_One,_Mr._Grinch
"You're a Mean One, Mr. Grinch")." His name was accidentally left out of the
credits, leading many to believe (erroneously) that the cartoon's narrator,
[Boris Karloff](/wiki/Boris_Karloff "Boris Karloff"), sang the song, while
others cited [Tennessee Ernie Ford](/wiki/Tennessee_Ernie_Ford "Tennessee
Ernie Ford") as the song's signature voice.[1]

Ravenscroft also sang "[No Dogs Allowed](/wiki/No_Dogs_Allowed "No Dogs
Allowed")" in the _[Peanuts](/wiki/Peanuts "Peanuts")_ animated motion picture
_[Snoopy, Come Home](/wiki/Snoopy,_Come_Home "Snoopy, Come Home")_ and _I Was
a Teenaged Brain Surgeon_ for [Spike Jones](/wiki/Spike_Jones "Spike Jones").

For more than 50 years, he was the uncredited voice of [Tony the
Tiger](/wiki/Tony_the_Tiger "Tony the Tiger") for [Kellogg's Frosted
Flakes](/wiki/Kellogg%27s_Frosted_Flakes "Kellogg's Frosted Flakes"). His
booming bass gave the cereal's tiger mascot a voice with the catchphrase
"They're g-r-r-r-eat!!!!".[8]

Various record companies, such as Abbott, Coral, Brunswick, and "X" (a
division of [RCA](/wiki/RCA "RCA")) also released singles by Ravenscroft,
often in duets with little-known female vocalists, in an attempt to turn the
bass-voiced veteran into a pop singer. These efforts were commercially
unsuccessful, if often quite interesting. He was also teamed up with [The
Andrews Sisters](/wiki/The_Andrews_Sisters "The Andrews Sisters") (on the [Dot
Records](/wiki/Dot_Records "Dot Records") album _The Andrews Sisters Present_)
on the cover of [Johnny Cymbal](/wiki/Johnny_Cymbal "Johnny Cymbal")'s "[Mr.
Bass Man](/wiki/Mr._Bass_Man "Mr. Bass Man")". The Mellomen released some
[doo-wop](/wiki/Doo-wop "Doo-wop") records under the name Big John & the
Buzzards, a name apparently given to them by the rock-and-roll-hating [Mitch
Miller](/wiki/Mitch_Miller "Mitch Miller"). His lifelong dream, which he
shared in an interview in 1999 with Peter Anthony Holder, was to record the
entire [Bible](/wiki/Bible "Bible") on tape, but [a big name
actor](/wiki/James_Earl_Jones "James Earl Jones") "beat him out". However,
being a devoted Christian, he appeared on many religious television shows such
as _[The Hour of Power](/wiki/The_Hour_of_Power "The Hour of Power")_. In
1970, he recorded an album called "Great Hymns in Story and Song", which
featured him singing 10 hymns, each prefaced with the stories of how each hymn
came to be, with the background vocals and instrumentals arranged and
conducted by [Ralph Carmichael](/wiki/Ralph_Carmichael "Ralph Carmichael").

## Later life and
death[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Thurl_Ravenscroft&action=edit&section=3 "Edit
section: Later life and death")]

Ravenscroft married June Seamans in 1946, and they had two children. June died
in 1999 from unknown causes. Ravenscroft semi-retired and did not work at any
other studio anymore, but he continued to voice Tony The Tiger through 2004
(with limo transportation by Kellogg's) and also submitted to an interview
that year by the Disney "Extinct Attractions Club" website. He died in his
home on May 22, 2005, from [prostate cancer](/wiki/Prostate_cancer "Prostate
cancer"). He was buried at the Memorial Gardens at the [Crystal
Cathedral](/wiki/Crystal_Cathedral "Crystal Cathedral") in [Garden Grove,
California](/wiki/Garden_Grove,_California "Garden Grove, California").[2]

In the June 6, 2005, issue of the advertising industry journal _[Advertising
Age](/wiki/Advertising_Age "Advertising Age")_ , Kellogg's ran an ad
commemorating Ravenscroft. The [headline](/wiki/Headline "Headline") read:
"Behind every great character is an even greater man." After his death, [Lee
Marshall](/wiki/Lee_Marshall_\(announcer\) "Lee Marshall \(announcer\)")
replaced him as the voice of Tony the Tiger in the Kellogg's commercials, but
some commercials still recycle clips of Ravenscroft.
